Class ec.e.util.crew.Queue 
All Packages  Class Hierarchy  This Package  Previous  Next  Index

Class ec.e.util.crew.Queue 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.e.util.crew.Queue
public class Queue
extends Object
A Queue is a stream of entries with two sides, the reader and the writer. The QueueReader will enumerate all the elements added to the queue so far, in the order they were written. Using the QueueWriter, one can add further entries to the queue, which the QueueReader will then be able to enumerate.

These queue classes are intended for multi-threaded use, but under a simplifying (and lock-reducing) assumption: Only one thread will be invoking the object at each side of the queue, so the queue can be used in a consumer/producer pattern between these two threads.

The Queue class itself is an artifact of not being able to return multiple values in Java. Better would have simply been to have a constructor that directly returned both reader and writer.

The Queue's internal data structure is a "half-party", it is half of the party data structure invented by Norm, Dean, et al, for use in Channels.

See Also:
QueueReader, QueueWriter

Queue()
Identical to Queue(null);
Queue(Object)
Creates a new Queue.

reader()
for consuming queue elements
writer()
for producing queue elements

Queue 
  public Queue(Object lock)
Creates a new Queue.
Parameters:
lock - nullOk; The lock passed in is the one to be used for synchronization. If the lock should be private to this queue, 'new Object()' is a fine expression for the lock argument. If 'lock' is null the QueueReader will complain (with a NoSuchElementException) rather than wait.
Queue 
  public Queue()
Identical to Queue(null);

reader 
  public QueueReader reader()
for consuming queue elements
writer 
  public QueueWriter writer()
for producing queue elements
